Well… ….yeah. Pretty much. The UK didn’t have much of its mighty Royal Navy in the South Pacific in 1942 to stop them. And the Dutch Navy in the East Indies went down pretty quickly at the battle of the Java sea. The Australian navy, an auxiliary force to the Royal Navy, simply wasn’t big enough to take on a Japanese Carrier task force and had lost a cruiser to a German raider and other cruisers in the east indies. Only the USA had the naval strength to tackle the Japanese navy.

After the Japanese bombed Darwin and established the Rabaul base there would have been great anxiety in Australia over the Japanese intentions. The battle of the Coral Sea helped the Australians keep New Guinea. The build up of many US troops in Australia and a thousand US made aircraft arriving in the next 12 months made Australia safe from Japanese invasion if they had changed their minds. The possibility of the moronic Blamey defending Australia without US assistance is stuff that nightmares are built on, even now. Fortunately Curtin was on to him.

I suggest New Zealand is a long way away from Japan. Why would they bother? As to Australia, there seems to be a view that Japan did not seriously intend to attack Australia - which would be as difficult for them to defend if captured as it was for us. After the USA developed its island hopping strategy, Japan had more to worry about. Australia was used by Macarthur as his base / refuge in Brisbane, Queensland after being ejected from the Philippines. Macarthur thought that Australians fighting the Japanese in New Guinea must have been shirking because there were not enough of us being killed. There were riots between US and Australian soldiers, with the immortal words “Over Paid, Over Sexed and Over Here”.
